title: M&S hackers claim responsibility for Jaguar Land Rover attack
description: The teenage hacking group that brought down Marks & Spencer has claimed responsibility for the cyber attack that has forced Jaguar Land Rover to shut down assembly lines.
content:
The teenage hacking group that brought down Marks & Spencer has claimed responsibility for the cyber attack that has forced Jaguar Land Rover to shut down assembly lines.

The cyber groups Scattered Spider and Shiny Hunters said they had been able to exploit a flaw in the carmaker’s IT systems. The groups said they had gained access to customer data.

This could leave JLR vulnerable to ransom demands as it scrambles to get its systems back online.

It is unclear if the company has been issued with a ransom demand or what data have been taken.

Scattered Spider, a loose collective of hackers, has been blamed for a series of major cyber disruptions in recent months – including the attacks on M&S, Co-op and Harrods. M&S has taken months to recover from the hack.

Scattered Spider is closely linked to a group known as Shiny Hunters, which said it was involved in targeting JLR.

The two groups now describe themselves as “one and the same” alongside the Lapsus group and now style themselves as “Scattered Lapsus Hunters”.

They are believed to be largely made up of teenagers and young men in English-speaking countries.

In July, three teenage males and a 20-year-old woman were arrested in association with the retail attacks.

A user on a Telegram messenger group linked to Scattered Spider and Shiny Hunters posted a screenshot appearing to show access to JLR’s internal systems.

A member of the group, identifying themself only as Shiny, told The Telegraph they had exploited a widely-known flaw in a third-party software provider to access customers’ data.

They did not say what type of data was taken or if they had issued a ransom demand.

The flaw – in software known as SAP Netweaver that is used to link different computer programs – allows hackers to remotely run code on a target’s computer systems.

The US cyber agency, CISA, warned about the flaw earlier this year amid reports that Chinese hackers were exploiting it. JLR uses the Netweaver software according to an online portal for accessing the company’s systems.

A software update to fix the flaw has been released but it is unclear whether JLR had applied it.

JLR said on Tuesday it had proactively shut down systems, a potential reference to the software the hackers claimed to have compromised.

The company said it had seen “no evidence” that data have been stolen, although this is rarely definitive in the early stages of an attack. Co-op, for example, initially said it had no evidence of data being taken before admitting that 6.5 million members had information stolen.

The Telegraph could not verify the hackers’ claims and JLR declined to comment on the identity of the attackers.
summary: The teenage hackers, Scattered Spider and Shiny Hunters, have claimed responsibility for a cyber attack that forced Jaguar Land Rover to shut down assembly lines. The groups exploited a flaw in the carmaker's IT systems to gain access to customer data, which could leave the company vulnerable to ransom demands. It is unclear if the company has received a ransom demand or what data was taken. The US cyber agency, CISA, warned about the flaw earlier this year amid reports that Chinese hackers were exploiting it. The hackers are believed to be largely made up of teenagers and young men in English-speaking countries.
shortSummary: Teenage hackers Scattered Spider and Shiny Hunters claimed responsibility for a cyber attack on Jaguar Land Rover, exploiting a security flaw in its IT systems to access customer data.
argos_summary: Teenage hacking group Scattered Spider, linked to Shiny Hunters, claims responsibility for a cyber attack that forced Jaguar Land Rover to shut down assembly lines. They exploited a flaw in SAP Netweaver to gain access to customer data, potentially exposing JLR to ransom demands. JLR has shut down systems and has not confirmed data theft, while the US CISA had warned about the vulnerability earlier this year. The attack adds to a series of disruptions by the group, including M&S, Co-op, and Harrods.
